body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

I did a blog post on this a while ago, though it was geared more toward the TRUE cost of abortion.

If one believes in original sin, which the bible says that all are born with a sin nature and we must be born again by accepting christ, then what does that mean for babies? If babies were born innocent then it is a supreme cruelty NOT to kill them, but to instead allow them to live and grow in a fallen world, and it is mercy to simply kill them and send them to heaven. If this were the case then the christian opposition to abortion is backward. This, however, is not the case, and most christians know it they just refuse to accept it (in all honestly most modern christians refuse to accept a lot of biblical truths, but that's another story). All this to say that a soul unsaved is a soul condemned by mans innate fallen sin nature, regardless of age. Is it horrible? Yes, and it should rally every christian to fight that much harder against the abortion industry who, in 2020, sent over 42 million souls to hell.

In all of this we must remember that God doesn't "let babies go to hell", the nature of man's free will and the fall are what send any soul to hell, it just so happens that satan has found a way to harvest a soul (for lack of a better term) before the opportunity to be exposed to the gospel. Its not a new tactic, but its been a long time since it was so widely accepted and popular. If satan has emotions he is likely giddy and the current state of the world. 42 million souls wrecked before they even had a chance to open their eyes. God have mercy on us.

If anyone is interested (https://snappertrx.wordpress.com/2019/11/07/the-horror-of-which-no-one-speaks/)

body:
God is both mercy and judgment, and it can be confidently asserted God would show mercy in such an instance.

Matthew 18:6
"But whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to sin, it would be better for him to have a great millstone fastened around his neck and to be drowned in the depth of the sea."

Matthew 18:10 
“See that you do not despise one of these little ones. For I tell you that in heaven their angels always see the face of my Father who is in heaven."

Mark 10:13-16 
"And they were bringing children to him that he might touch them, and the disciples rebuked them. But when Jesus saw it, he was indignant and said to them, “Let the children come to me; do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of God. Truly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child shall not enter it.” And he took them in his arms and blessed them, laying his hands on them."

body:
God wants us all in Heaven. He doesn’t want to separate people from Himself.

I don’t think babies/young children have enough understanding to accept or reject God. I believe God is of mercy, love, and justice and appropriately applies them. It seems to me God intends for everyone to have some knowledge or seeking towards Him before they die, some people in places where the Gospel isn’t preached Jesus has appeared in visions or dreams. The Bible says the beauty and majesty of nature points to a Creator. I believe babies and small children that have passed away are likely to grow up in Heaven with all the knowledge of God. Some people with visions of Heaven on the verge of death have reported seeing lost siblings or siblings never seen from miscarriages. So I think it makes the most sense.

>“Whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in Me to sin, it would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck, and he were drowned in the depth of the sea.  Woe to the world because of offenses! For offenses must come, but woe to that man by whom the offense comes! “If your hand or foot causes you to sin, cut it off and cast it from you. It is better for you to enter into life lame or maimed, rather than having two hands or two feet, to be cast into the everlasting fire.  And if your eye causes you to sin, pluck it out and cast it from you. It is better for you to enter into life with one eye, rather than having two eyes, to be cast into hell fire. “Take heed that you do not despise one of these little ones, for I say to you that in heaven their angels always see the face of My Father who is in heaven.  For the Son of Man has come to save that which was lost. “What do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep, and one of them goes astray, does he not leave the ninety-nine and go to the mountains to seek the one that is straying?  And if he should find it, assuredly, I say to you, he rejoices more over that sheep than over the ninety-nine that did not go astray.  Even so it is not the will of your Father who is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body: Frank Turek has several videos where he addresses questions you have. So first, about people who never heard. There are people who just won't believe even if you told them about Jesus. On the other hand there are people who are open to Jesus (but they don't know about that yet) Turek says (and I also believe this is true) that If God sees, you are genuinely looking for Him, he'll make himself known to you. It could be through dreams, or maybe a vision (if other 'contact' is not possible). Around us, there is enough evidence to come to conclusion that a God (our, Christian God) exists. So I think it is not impossible for people to realise that there is one true God, who created all of this. This also gives an answer to babies born in non-christian places.  (I highly recommend watching videos on his channel Cross Examined, where he posts short videos of him answering various questions. They are short, and I think he explains the problems really well.)

Babies, while fallen, are innocent beings. They're going to heaven for sure. God is love.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

Counter argument...

> Romans 3:21 But now apart from the law the righteousness of God (although it is attested by the law and the prophets) has been disclosed— 22 namely, the righteousness of God through the faithfulness of Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction, **for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.**

> Romans 2:14  For whenever the Gentiles, who do not have the law, do by nature the things required by the law, these who do not have the law are a law to themselves. 15 They show that the work of the law is written in their hearts, as their conscience bears witness and their conflicting thoughts accuse **or else defend them**, 16 on the day when God will judge the secrets of human hearts, according to my gospel through Christ Jesus.

Taken together, to me this seems to indicate that condemnation comes _not_ from some vague imprint of original sin — not by the sinful nature itself (a propensity towards sin), but through each person _actually sinning_ (which is pretty much guaranteed to happen as soon as we are old enough given our sin nature). Can an unborn baby, then, actually commit sin? I would say no. At what point can we say that a baby/toddler/child is consciously committing sin? I think it's different for every human being based on their own individual development, and thanks be to God that we aren't the ones that have to judge that.

Why is abortion bad, then, if it's committing a kindness by sending babies to heaven? Because it's against God's moral law and specific (6th) commandment — it requires a deep depravity and perversion of God's created order — parents are created to love, protect, provide for, and train their children, not kill them. Doing so perverts nature and profanes the name and image of God.

> Leviticus 18:21 You must not give any of your children as an offering to Molech (i.e., kill them as a sacrifice to an idol), **so that you do not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord!** 22 You must not have sexual relations with a male as one has sexual relations with a woman; it is a detestable act.

> Jeremiah 32:35 They built places of worship for the god Baal in the Valley of Ben Hinnom so that they could sacrifice their sons and daughters to the god Molech. _Such a **disgusting practice** was not something I commanded them to do. It never even entered my mind to command them to do such a thing!_ So Judah is certainly liable for punishment.’

A similar situation can be found in Judas Iscariot:

> 23 He answered, “The one who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me will betray me. 24 The Son of Man will go _as it is written about him_, **but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would be better for him if he had never been born**.” 25 Then Judas, the one who would betray him, said, “Surely not I, Rabbi?” Jesus replied, “You have said it yourself.”

One could argue that salvation for all of human kind came about from the betrayal of Judas — inarguably a good thing, just like babies going to heaven — and God even wrote that it would happen ahead of time, so wouldn't Judas have been doing a good thing? No, he still committed an evil act of betraying the son of God and will be held accountable for it. God can and does bring about good from evil (e.g., Joseph being sold into slavery), but that still doesn't excuse evil in the first place. In other words, God can bring good out of evil acts, but could he not bring out _more_ good from good acts? The aborted baby may go to heaven, but what are the spiritual (let alone physical) ramifications for the parents, doctors, family, society, and anyone else involved in allowing that to happen? How much good might have come out from allowing the baby to live and (potentially) fulfill a Godly purpose for their life reaching other lost people?

I'm certainly not going to be dogmatic about any of this, but would be interested in further discussion.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
Hell is for those who understand Christ and reject His character and works of divinity or confound Him as something evil.

My understanding is there are 6 actions that will keep you from the Kingdom of God.

1. Presumption, coming from pride, the sin of believing one can get to heaven alone. One who believes they are not in need of salvation despite actions.
2. Obstinacy, coming from pride, the stubbornness of refusing grace because they believe all their actions to be entirely righteous.
3. Impenitence, coming from gluttony and greed, simply one who is unrepentant of their actions without the care of salvation.
4. Despair, coming from sloth, where one concludes that their sin dwarfs His power and goodness and therefore cannot be saved. Denial of the concept of salvation
5. Envy of brothers spiritual good, Envy of the increase in grace.
6. Resistance to truth - knowing that Jesus is the way, the truth, and the life.

This is why I think generally speaking that unbaptized children will be accepted into the kingdom of heaven.  They are incapable of such actions

God wants us all in Heaven. He doesn’t want to separate people from Himself.

I don’t think babies/young children have enough understanding to accept or reject God. I believe God is of mercy, love, and justice and appropriately applies them. It seems to me God intends for everyone to have some knowledge or seeking towards Him before they die, some people in places where the Gospel isn’t preached Jesus has appeared in visions or dreams. The Bible says the beauty and majesty of nature points to a Creator. I believe babies and small children that have passed away are likely to grow up in Heaven with all the knowledge of God. Some people with visions of Heaven on the verge of death have reported seeing lost siblings or siblings never seen from miscarriages. So I think it makes the most sense.

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
I also look at it simply as "the Bible is God's word. He sent us his message to be read or spread by word of mouth."

Babies, even toddlers and young children cannot read, comprehend or even begin to understand the concept of salvation. By God's own word, they cannot be expected to be held accountable or punished for their actions(wages of sin is death, etc.) they have no way to sin OR comprehend that they've sinned, up to a certain age. I always assumed this was common knowledge or belief, but it sounds like there's technicalities afoot.

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

“Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon **all men**, for that all have sinned:”

- Romans 5:12 (KJV)

“Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in **sin** did my mother **conceive** me.”

- Psalm 51:5 (KJV)

*A man's age has no bearing on the fact that he is a sinner and will go to hell upon death should he not obey the Gospel of salvation which is:*

“Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost.”

- Acts 2:38 (KJV)

*As it is also written:*

“Jesus answered, Verily, verily, I say unto thee, **Except** a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he **cannot** enter into the kingdom of God.”

- John 3:5 (KJV)

*May this short message be a blessing to those of you who love the Lord Jesus Christ and have ears to hear.*

“He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.”

- Matthew 11:15 (KJV)

Amen.


/Thumper

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
I wonder then, why would you *not* follow God if He judges infants to be destined to hell?

This question you ask makes me less convinced of your arguments, not more, as I feel like it confirms my suspicion that people mainly believe babies go to heaven because they *want* that to be true. You even state it as a **condition** to follow God. I can't help but feel like it's to some extend sin that is behind this conviction, being pride. God is most important by far, He is more important than babies are to us and He is righteousness. We are to be His steward with our whole being.

To answer your question then: yes, I would still follow Him. In fact pondering on it further it only seems fair if babies go to hell since as fallen man all deserve hell to great extend, even those who never heard the gospel and never got the choice to believe in Christ and 99% of people before Christ was even here. We may underestimate the amount of grace we face with Christ.

And actually now I think about it, with certain prespective it then makes God seem even more beautiful and higher in mercy with how He sent Christ to save us despite how far we are fallen. It makes you even more thankful for God's grace and it immensily motivates you to preach the Word and save children.

Then, when you save a baby or child, you  do it as a command from God and to have them potentially do greater acts, but you then also expose them to the risk of damnation. Doesn't the act of saving children become paradoxical then? Wouldn't it make us selfish and greedy if we saved children their lives and proceed to then threaten their salvation, just to save our own? Or does the potential of greater acts trump that? I have trouble coming to grips with that morally. It demotivates me to save children or care for them when it comes down to it as it seems a much greater mercy if they die. Beside that, life seems like a curse to babies growing up before Christ and babies growing up in places where the gospel will never be heard of. To be brutally honest, it seems unfair to me if babies do get saved then, but what's fair is not for me to determine.

I'm also afraid that the main reasoning for believing babies to go to heaven is the fact everybody *wants* this to be true because we have a special feeling towards babies, which fades as they grow older. Is this truly fair reasoning though as it's arguably a primal instinct of ours to feel this way towards babies while not caring nearly as much about those not able to receive the Gospel due to circumstances? 

Aren't we too indulged in sinful pride when we can't fathom that human babies may be sinful from birth? Deciding that it would be unrighteous? Pride which partly covers us from God? Would you still follow God if you knew that he does condemn babies to hell?

The quotes conerning the law seem to me to be more of a warning that following the jewish law isn't a guarantee to heaven. And the gentiles it speaks of may as well be believers in Christ without being in possesion of the jewish law. They are also to be judged by Christ in the end although I can see different interpretations to that.

There's also these quotes posted here by @Thumper

“Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:”
    • Romans 5:12 (KJV)
“Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in sin did my mother conceive me.”
    • Psalm 51:5 (KJV)

Which may argue that when born we personally have already sinned in Adam, and that our only salvation is then to be saved in Christ. 

What's also problematic is the fact that children become sinful *very* quickly as any parent can attest to I'm sure. At 3 year old they are for sure sinning in all kinds of ways, however they are yet incapable of taking the message of Christ to heart. Does this mean they are screwed when they die then no matter what? While they *would* have been saved if they died 2 years ago?

parent.body:
Counter argument...

> Romans 3:21 But now apart from the law the righteousness of God (although it is attested by the law and the prophets) has been disclosed— 22 namely, the righteousness of God through the faithfulness of Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction, **for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.**

> Romans 2:14  For whenever the Gentiles, who do not have the law, do by nature the things required by the law, these who do not have the law are a law to themselves. 15 They show that the work of the law is written in their hearts, as their conscience bears witness and their conflicting thoughts accuse **or else defend them**, 16 on the day when God will judge the secrets of human hearts, according to my gospel through Christ Jesus.

Taken together, to me this seems to indicate that condemnation comes _not_ from some vague imprint of original sin — not by the sinful nature itself (a propensity towards sin), but through each person _actually sinning_ (which is pretty much guaranteed to happen as soon as we are old enough given our sin nature). Can an unborn baby, then, actually commit sin? I would say no. At what point can we say that a baby/toddler/child is consciously committing sin? I think it's different for every human being based on their own individual development, and thanks be to God that we aren't the ones that have to judge that.

Why is abortion bad, then, if it's committing a kindness by sending babies to heaven? Because it's against God's moral law and specific (6th) commandment — it requires a deep depravity and perversion of God's created order — parents are created to love, protect, provide for, and train their children, not kill them. Doing so perverts nature and profanes the name and image of God.

> Leviticus 18:21 You must not give any of your children as an offering to Molech (i.e., kill them as a sacrifice to an idol), **so that you do not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord!** 22 You must not have sexual relations with a male as one has sexual relations with a woman; it is a detestable act.

> Jeremiah 32:35 They built places of worship for the god Baal in the Valley of Ben Hinnom so that they could sacrifice their sons and daughters to the god Molech. _Such a **disgusting practice** was not something I commanded them to do. It never even entered my mind to command them to do such a thing!_ So Judah is certainly liable for punishment.’

A similar situation can be found in Judas Iscariot:

> 23 He answered, “The one who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me will betray me. 24 The Son of Man will go _as it is written about him_, **but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would be better for him if he had never been born**.” 25 Then Judas, the one who would betray him, said, “Surely not I, Rabbi?” Jesus replied, “You have said it yourself.”

One could argue that salvation for all of human kind came about from the betrayal of Judas — inarguably a good thing, just like babies going to heaven — and God even wrote that it would happen ahead of time, so wouldn't Judas have been doing a good thing? No, he still committed an evil act of betraying the son of God and will be held accountable for it. God can and does bring about good from evil (e.g., Joseph being sold into slavery), but that still doesn't excuse evil in the first place. In other words, God can bring good out of evil acts, but could he not bring out _more_ good from good acts? The aborted baby may go to heaven, but what are the spiritual (let alone physical) ramifications for the parents, doctors, family, society, and anyone else involved in allowing that to happen? How much good might have come out from allowing the baby to live and (potentially) fulfill a Godly purpose for their life reaching other lost people?

I'm certainly not going to be dogmatic about any of this, but would be interested in further discussion.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
> but you then also expose them to the risk of damnation

Is that not what life is? Is God himself not exposing us all to that risk through the act of creation? If we deem in our own limited understanding that it would be better for someone to never be born, then are we not usurping God's authority and, in a way, trying to foil from the very outset the plans he has for those people? 

> Wouldn't it make us selfish and greedy if we saved children their lives and proceed to then threaten their salvation, just to save our own?

This is a foolish argument. Is it ever selfish and greedy to follow the commandments of God and the natural created order — even if it seems counterintuitive to us (Isa 55:9 As the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts than your thoughts.)? This is especially foolish when you realize that the reasons given _for_ aborting babies are selfishness and greed ("I'm not ready", "It would be too hard", "It's not convenient right now", "I have to think of my career", "I can't afford it", etc.). Furthermore, the Bible is pretty clear that we are not to commit evil acts even if the ends are good; the means are just as important as the ends.

This whole line of argumentation is about the same as one we could make for just killing someone as soon as they are saved (regardless of their age). I mean, why doesn't God himself just end our life as soon as our election is secured? To think that either is acceptable is to second guess God and try to usurp his authority, and to anyone that would still be struggling with these notions, perhaps we can only lean on the conclusion at then end of Ecclesiastes: 12:8 “Meaningless! Meaningless!” says the Teacher. “Everything is meaningless!” ... 13 Now all has been heard; here is the conclusion of the matter: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the duty of all mankind. 14 For God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing, whether it is good or evil.

Why do we not kill babies (or anyone with a right standing before God) in order to send them straight to heaven? Because God said so.

> I have trouble coming to grips with that morally. It demotivates me to save children or care for them when it comes down to it as it seems a much greater mercy if they die.

Morals are not in a vacuum (they are from God), and we often forget that we cannot see the big picture that God can. Perhaps you are saving that one person — even at the expense of your own damnation — but again, what are the effects of that one life going to be... perhaps by taking that one baby's life, you are condemning dozens or hundreds more to hell 40 years down the road. You don't know, and that's the point. We don't know the future, so it is to us to trust and obey God in the present, even when it may not make sense to us.

> Beside that, life seems like a curse to babies growing up before Christ

So was everyone before Christ was born condemned to hell? No. There were still people justified by faith (Abraham is a good example) and Christ's sacrifice extended in both directions in human history.

> and babies growing up in places where the gospel will never be heard of. 

Again, we don't know the future. Will that child always remain in the area? Will that area never hear the Gospel? Will that child bring the gospel to that area? We don't know: obey God.

> the main reasoning for believing babies to go to heaven is the fact everybody _wants_ this to be true because we have a special feeling towards babies

No. I would say that this argument is born from the fact that God is righteous and will not condemn people for anything but their own sins (Ezekiel 18). An individual human, then, who has not yet sinned would therefore _not_ be condemned by a righteous God. At what point would a child be capable of sin? I don't know — God knows. It's going to be different for every single person, and having young kids of my own, terrifies me that for every human there's likely a gap there where they are consciously sinning, but before they accept salvation — and why training up kids in the light of the gospel from birth is so important. To me, in order to believe that unborn infants would go to hell, you would have to believe in some form of the Roman Catholic version of original sin, which I do not. I believe that we are born with a fallen sinful _nature_, a propensity towards sin, but a _propensity_ towards sin is not sin itself any more than a mental or biological propensity towards alcoholism gets you drunk.

> Is this truly fair reasoning though as it's arguably a primal instinct of ours to feel this way towards babies while not caring nearly as much about those not able to receive the Gospel due to circumstances?

Part of our sanctification — becoming more Christlike — is to grow that feeling of deep concern for the lost. Why does it seem wrong or unfair that we care more about babies? Because it _is_ wrong and broken and unfair — and that's part of our sinful nature that has to be corrected. But these are two _different_ problems. Caring for the shedding of innocent blood on the one hand, and reaching out to the lost on the other. They are both critically important, but both require different responses and solutions — I would argue that it's kind of an apples and oranges comparison.

> Aren't we too indulged in sinful pride when we can't fathom that human babies may be sinful from birth? Deciding that it would be unrighteous? Pride which partly covers us from God?

No. I would point back to the same argument in Eze 18. God is righteous and _has plainly said_ that he only condemns people for their own sins. You conscience, placed in you by God, should be telling you that this is right and fair.

> Would you still follow God if you knew that he does condemn babies to hell?

I would follow God because there is no other to follow. After reading Eze 18 (and thanks for provoking me to find that), I am 100% sure that God judges all fairly — regardless of their age. Anything more has to be left to trusting him.

> The quotes concerning the law seem to me to be more of a warning that following the jewish law isn't a guarantee to heaven. 

Yes, but the main point is what I bolded: all have sinned — not all are tainted by Adam's original sin, or a sin nature, or something like that — but all _have sinned_. It is by their individual sins that each individual person is condemned, and even the Jews, as righteous as they are, still have each individually, down to a person, committed sins. That's even part of the Romans 5:12 ... which indicates that a sin-nature (a propensity for sin) has entered the world, it is still each individual's sin that leads to death and condemnation: "and so death passed upon all men, for that **all have sinned**."

> What's also problematic is the fact that children become sinful very quickly as any parent can attest to I'm sure. At 3 year old they are for sure sinning in all kinds of ways, however they are yet incapable of taking the message of Christ to heart. Does this mean they are screwed when they die then no matter what? While they would have been saved if they died 2 years ago?

I agree that this is scary. For what it's worth, I have seen people who have (claimed) to be saved as early as 4. None of the scariness or uncertainty during the early childhood years negates any of the arguments I made above, though. Yes, life in this crappy, evil, fallen world is full of uncertainty, unfairness, evil, and things that are scary. The answer: Ecc 12:13 Fear God and keep his commandments.

parent.body:
Then, when you save a baby or child, you  do it as a command from God and to have them potentially do greater acts, but you then also expose them to the risk of damnation. Doesn't the act of saving children become paradoxical then? Wouldn't it make us selfish and greedy if we saved children their lives and proceed to then threaten their salvation, just to save our own? Or does the potential of greater acts trump that? I have trouble coming to grips with that morally. It demotivates me to save children or care for them when it comes down to it as it seems a much greater mercy if they die. Beside that, life seems like a curse to babies growing up before Christ and babies growing up in places where the gospel will never be heard of. To be brutally honest, it seems unfair to me if babies do get saved then, but what's fair is not for me to determine.

I'm also afraid that the main reasoning for believing babies to go to heaven is the fact everybody *wants* this to be true because we have a special feeling towards babies, which fades as they grow older. Is this truly fair reasoning though as it's arguably a primal instinct of ours to feel this way towards babies while not caring nearly as much about those not able to receive the Gospel due to circumstances? 

Aren't we too indulged in sinful pride when we can't fathom that human babies may be sinful from birth? Deciding that it would be unrighteous? Pride which partly covers us from God? Would you still follow God if you knew that he does condemn babies to hell?

The quotes conerning the law seem to me to be more of a warning that following the jewish law isn't a guarantee to heaven. And the gentiles it speaks of may as well be believers in Christ without being in possesion of the jewish law. They are also to be judged by Christ in the end although I can see different interpretations to that.

There's also these quotes posted here by @Thumper

“Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:”
    • Romans 5:12 (KJV)
“Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in sin did my mother conceive me.”
    • Psalm 51:5 (KJV)

Which may argue that when born we personally have already sinned in Adam, and that our only salvation is then to be saved in Christ. 

What's also problematic is the fact that children become sinful *very* quickly as any parent can attest to I'm sure. At 3 year old they are for sure sinning in all kinds of ways, however they are yet incapable of taking the message of Christ to heart. Does this mean they are screwed when they die then no matter what? While they *would* have been saved if they died 2 years ago?

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
My argument is that it may be pride in our bond with babies *making us believe* that it would be righteous for babies to go to heaven in the first place. God is righteosness and what we believe or feel towards babies falls short of it, it's pride that makes us believe that we do know what is or isn't righteous as opposed to trusting God. 

I don't believe conscience is relevant here, as concience would relate to our own morality in regards to our own actions. It doesn't seem to be about other's how I understand it or what afterlife would be fair for given person. Although this might be a rather semantic argument which may not be relevant to what you mean.

>This is a foolish argument

The paradox is no more when you would accept babies to go to hell. It's also not just about abortion, it could be e.g. that a baby has some illness and you decide on whether or not to treat it. Our primal instinct will make us want to save them but any other animal (mammal) would have the same instinct, we aren't special in that regard. The reasons you give that we are to follow God's command are still within the paradox: you do it all just to save your *own* salvation. When thinking pure utilitarian there is no reason to murder another human when they are saved already as they help the mission and there's also no reason to kill the non-believers as you then condemn them to hell without giving the chance of future salvation. 

I understand your argument of God's commandments being absolute and that even the destined non-believers play a role in God's plan and that we are to love them all the same. The thing that I really want to stress is it's assumed that these non-believers *had* salvation if they only died younger. They had **eternal** salvation if only they died as a baby. They had it, but then lost it. From a certain perspective this seems very unjust. The fact we all deserve hell to great extend only makes sense if this includes babies as well. 

As for Ezekiel 18, as you said, Christ saved in both ways in the timeline. The standards for being saved by the Christ were different before and after Christ. Those who followed the law dilligently and had taken favor with God were still sinners yet saved (and I doubt there were many who did) but this no longer applies to us since Christ is in our past. Nobody gets saved by only following the law now. Everybody needs Christ. They are to connect with God again and be saved.  

That said, let me quote a fuller version of what I cited in previous post:

>Therefore, just as through one man sin entered the world, and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men, because all sinned— (For until the law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law. Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned according to the likeness of the transgression of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come. But the free gift is not like the offense. For if by the one man’s offense many died, much more the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one Man, Jesus Christ, abounded to many. And the gift is not like that  which  came through the one who sinned. For the judgment which  came from one offense  resulted in condemnation, but the free gift which  came from many offenses resulted in justification. For if by the one man’s offense death reigned through the one, much more those who receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life through the One, Jesus Christ.)
Romans 5:12‭-‬17 NKJV

You see, Adam initially had the Holy Spirit and was directly in connection with God in eternal life. The Holy Spirit was the dominant force and the body was his servant. However, after Adam sinned, body became dominant and Adam his connection was cut from God, and because of this he met with death. Not only Adam, but all of his offspring were cut from God and were no longer born in God's image, but in their own likeness as a man of nature and with mind of flesh into death. What Christ did was offer the immense grace of restoring this bond with God. Trough the Holy Spirit we may again be in direct connection with God and thus be saved. 

Again, we are no longer born in God's image, our very (spiritual) being has changed after Adam's sin. This would lead me to believe there's no reason babies would be saved as man had changed fundamentally in image and the Spirit simply isn't there. If babies *would* be saved it would be a direct intervention from God and an exception to the rule it seems since they naturally don't have a connection to God, and it's not the same way Christ may have saved the chosen people from before His time since that has already happened, which was a 1 time event I assume?

I understand your argument of God's commandments being absolute and that even the destined non-believers play a role in God's plan and that we are to love them all the same. The thing that I really want to stress is it's assumed that these non-believers had salvation if they only died younger. They had eternal salvation if only they died as a baby. They had it, but then lost it. From a certain perspective this seems very unjust. The fact we all deserve hell to great extend only makes sense if this includes babies as well.

As for Ezekiel 18, as you said, Christ saved in both ways in the timeline. The standards for being saved by the Christ were different before and after Christ. Those who followed the law dilligently and had taken favor with God were still sinners yet saved (and I doubt there were many who did) but this no longer applies to us since Christ is in our past. Nobody gets saved by only following the law now. Everybody needs Christ. They are to connect with God again and be saved.

That said, let me quote a fuller version of what I cited in previous post:

Therefore, just as through one man sin entered the world, and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men, because all sinned— (For until the law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law. Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned according to the likeness of the transgression of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come. But the free gift is not like the offense. For if by the one man’s offense many died, much more the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one Man, Jesus Christ, abounded to many. And the gift is not like that which came through the one who sinned. For the judgment which came from one offense resulted in condemnation, but the free gift which came from many offenses resulted in justification. For if by the one man’s offense death reigned through the one, much more those who receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life through the One, Jesus Christ.) Romans 5:12‭-‬17 NKJV

You see, Adam initially had the Holy Spirit and was directly in connection with God in eternal life. The Holy Spirit was the dominant force and the body was his servant. However, after Adam sinned, body became dominant and Adam his connection was cut from God, and because of this he met with death. Not only Adam, but all of his offspring were cut from God and were no longer born in God's image, but in their own likeness as a man of nature and with mind of flesh into death. What Christ did was offer the immense grace of restoring this bond with God. Trough the Holy Spirit we may again be in direct connection with God and thus be saved.

Again, we are no longer born in God's image, our very (spiritual) being has changed after Adam's sin. This would lead me to believe there's no reason babies would be saved as man had changed fundamentally in image and the Spirit simply isn't there. If babies would be saved it would be a direct intervention from God and an exception to the rule it seems since they naturally don't have a connection to God, and it's not the same way Christ may have saved the chosen people from before His time since that has already happened, which was a 1 time event I assume?

> but you then also expose them to the risk of damnation

Is that not what life is? Is God himself not exposing us all to that risk through the act of creation? If we deem in our own limited understanding that it would be better for someone to never be born, then are we not usurping God's authority and, in a way, trying to foil from the very outset the plans he has for those people? 

> Wouldn't it make us selfish and greedy if we saved children their lives and proceed to then threaten their salvation, just to save our own?

This is a foolish argument. Is it ever selfish and greedy to follow the commandments of God and the natural created order — even if it seems counterintuitive to us (Isa 55:9 As the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts than your thoughts.)? This is especially foolish when you realize that the reasons given _for_ aborting babies are selfishness and greed ("I'm not ready", "It would be too hard", "It's not convenient right now", "I have to think of my career", "I can't afford it", etc.). Furthermore, the Bible is pretty clear that we are not to commit evil acts even if the ends are good; the means are just as important as the ends.

This whole line of argumentation is about the same as one we could make for just killing someone as soon as they are saved (regardless of their age). I mean, why doesn't God himself just end our life as soon as our election is secured? To think that either is acceptable is to second guess God and try to usurp his authority, and to anyone that would still be struggling with these notions, perhaps we can only lean on the conclusion at then end of Ecclesiastes: 12:8 “Meaningless! Meaningless!” says the Teacher. “Everything is meaningless!” ... 13 Now all has been heard; here is the conclusion of the matter: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the duty of all mankind. 14 For God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing, whether it is good or evil.

Why do we not kill babies (or anyone with a right standing before God) in order to send them straight to heaven? Because God said so.

> I have trouble coming to grips with that morally. It demotivates me to save children or care for them when it comes down to it as it seems a much greater mercy if they die.

Morals are not in a vacuum (they are from God), and we often forget that we cannot see the big picture that God can. Perhaps you are saving that one person — even at the expense of your own damnation — but again, what are the effects of that one life going to be... perhaps by taking that one baby's life, you are condemning dozens or hundreds more to hell 40 years down the road. You don't know, and that's the point. We don't know the future, so it is to us to trust and obey God in the present, even when it may not make sense to us.

> Beside that, life seems like a curse to babies growing up before Christ

So was everyone before Christ was born condemned to hell? No. There were still people justified by faith (Abraham is a good example) and Christ's sacrifice extended in both directions in human history.

> and babies growing up in places where the gospel will never be heard of. 

Again, we don't know the future. Will that child always remain in the area? Will that area never hear the Gospel? Will that child bring the gospel to that area? We don't know: obey God.

> the main reasoning for believing babies to go to heaven is the fact everybody _wants_ this to be true because we have a special feeling towards babies

No. I would say that this argument is born from the fact that God is righteous and will not condemn people for anything but their own sins (Ezekiel 18). An individual human, then, who has not yet sinned would therefore _not_ be condemned by a righteous God. At what point would a child be capable of sin? I don't know — God knows. It's going to be different for every single person, and having young kids of my own, terrifies me that for every human there's likely a gap there where they are consciously sinning, but before they accept salvation — and why training up kids in the light of the gospel from birth is so important. To me, in order to believe that unborn infants would go to hell, you would have to believe in some form of the Roman Catholic version of original sin, which I do not. I believe that we are born with a fallen sinful _nature_, a propensity towards sin, but a _propensity_ towards sin is not sin itself any more than a mental or biological propensity towards alcoholism gets you drunk.

> Is this truly fair reasoning though as it's arguably a primal instinct of ours to feel this way towards babies while not caring nearly as much about those not able to receive the Gospel due to circumstances?

Part of our sanctification — becoming more Christlike — is to grow that feeling of deep concern for the lost. Why does it seem wrong or unfair that we care more about babies? Because it _is_ wrong and broken and unfair — and that's part of our sinful nature that has to be corrected. But these are two _different_ problems. Caring for the shedding of innocent blood on the one hand, and reaching out to the lost on the other. They are both critically important, but both require different responses and solutions — I would argue that it's kind of an apples and oranges comparison.

> Aren't we too indulged in sinful pride when we can't fathom that human babies may be sinful from birth? Deciding that it would be unrighteous? Pride which partly covers us from God?

No. I would point back to the same argument in Eze 18. God is righteous and _has plainly said_ that he only condemns people for their own sins. You conscience, placed in you by God, should be telling you that this is right and fair.

> Would you still follow God if you knew that he does condemn babies to hell?

I would follow God because there is no other to follow. After reading Eze 18 (and thanks for provoking me to find that), I am 100% sure that God judges all fairly — regardless of their age. Anything more has to be left to trusting him.

> The quotes concerning the law seem to me to be more of a warning that following the jewish law isn't a guarantee to heaven. 

Yes, but the main point is what I bolded: all have sinned — not all are tainted by Adam's original sin, or a sin nature, or something like that — but all _have sinned_. It is by their individual sins that each individual person is condemned, and even the Jews, as righteous as they are, still have each individually, down to a person, committed sins. That's even part of the Romans 5:12 ... which indicates that a sin-nature (a propensity for sin) has entered the world, it is still each individual's sin that leads to death and condemnation: "and so death passed upon all men, for that **all have sinned**."

> What's also problematic is the fact that children become sinful very quickly as any parent can attest to I'm sure. At 3 year old they are for sure sinning in all kinds of ways, however they are yet incapable of taking the message of Christ to heart. Does this mean they are screwed when they die then no matter what? While they would have been saved if they died 2 years ago?

I agree that this is scary. For what it's worth, I have seen people who have (claimed) to be saved as early as 4. None of the scariness or uncertainty during the early childhood years negates any of the arguments I made above, though. Yes, life in this crappy, evil, fallen world is full of uncertainty, unfairness, evil, and things that are scary. The answer: Ecc 12:13 Fear God and keep his commandments.

It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

body:
I'm surprised how debated this is, because the answer while not directly addressed seems rather clear to me:

> If I had not come and spoken to them, **they would not be guilty of sin**.

> But the one who unknowingly does things worthy of punishment will be beaten with few blows.

(Note that "few" is often used in the sense of none in the NT)

This should address the fate of anyone who hasn't heard: the unevangelized, children too young to understand, animals, the mentally insane, and of course unborn babies. They cannot be considered guilty of something they know nothing about. Of course it is still important to share it with those who can understand it, since they are still lost in a hopeless world otherwise. But condemnation comes only to those who willingly reject it, the same way Adam and Eve had to choose to eat from the forbidden tree knowing full well they shouldn't.

post.body:
It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

parent.body:
Hell is for those who understand Christ and reject His character and works of divinity or confound Him as something evil.

My understanding is there are 6 actions that will keep you from the Kingdom of God.

1. Presumption, coming from pride, the sin of believing one can get to heaven alone. One who believes they are not in need of salvation despite actions.
2. Obstinacy, coming from pride, the stubbornness of refusing grace because they believe all their actions to be entirely righteous.
3. Impenitence, coming from gluttony and greed, simply one who is unrepentant of their actions without the care of salvation.
4. Despair, coming from sloth, where one concludes that their sin dwarfs His power and goodness and therefore cannot be saved. Denial of the concept of salvation
5. Envy of brothers spiritual good, Envy of the increase in grace.
6. Resistance to truth - knowing that Jesus is the way, the truth, and the life.

This is why I think generally speaking that unbaptized children will be accepted into the kingdom of heaven.  They are incapable of such actions

It's a question often throwed at Christians: Do babies go to heaven(/hell)? 

I don't know the answer to this, but the consensus everywhere I look seems to be that they do go to heaven. I want to believe that but I have difficulty in making sense of it. **The passages from scripture that claim one way or the other don't seem real proof to me when read in context.**

Does that mean that babies who are born in environments where the gospel will never be preached or available are better off dead than ever grow up? Cause they won't be introduced to Christ when they do grow up so heaven won't be accessible then, but it is when they die as a baby?

It's really harsh to consider that babies would potentially go to hell, but outside of that there's the harsh established reality that we all deserve hell. We are sinful in nature due to Adam's original sin and Christ was sent to us as an immense grace from God, which we are to cherish with our whole being if we are to be saved. Salvation isn't owed to us at all, we don't deserve it whatsoever.

This means that your non-believing neighbour who's the kindest person you have ever met is also destined to hell, as well as people born into slave camps in North-Korrea who never heard the gospel. Why do babies deserve heaven then I wonder? Because they aren't accountable? People who never heard of the gospel seem to me just as unaccountable as babies when it comes to salvation. Why are babies special here? If you have never heard the gospel as adult you could never have made the choice to believe in Christ, yet you are still going to hell because salvation is not owed to anyone. I have then trouble processing how babies would get a pass nonethless.

I truly don't know at the moment. And I fear the subject is too emotional for many people to have a genuine look on it. (Maybe it's sinful pride that makes the idea of babies going to hell unfathomable?)

Either way, we can safely trust that God will do what's right so perhaps it's not even a useful discussion to have, perhaps there's not even a clear cut simple answer this. 

Still, help me out if you can.

Then, when you save a baby or child, you  do it as a command from God and to have them potentially do greater acts, but you then also expose them to the risk of damnation. Doesn't the act of saving children become paradoxical then? Wouldn't it make us selfish and greedy if we saved children their lives and proceed to then threaten their salvation, just to save our own? Or does the potential of greater acts trump that? I have trouble coming to grips with that morally. It demotivates me to save children or care for them when it comes down to it as it seems a much greater mercy if they die. Beside that, life seems like a curse to babies growing up before Christ and babies growing up in places where the gospel will never be heard of. To be brutally honest, it seems unfair to me if babies do get saved then, but what's fair is not for me to determine.

I'm also afraid that the main reasoning for believing babies to go to heaven is the fact everybody *wants* this to be true because we have a special feeling towards babies, which fades as they grow older. Is this truly fair reasoning though as it's arguably a primal instinct of ours to feel this way towards babies while not caring nearly as much about those not able to receive the Gospel due to circumstances? 

Aren't we too indulged in sinful pride when we can't fathom that human babies may be sinful from birth? Deciding that it would be unrighteous? Pride which partly covers us from God? Would you still follow God if you knew that he does condemn babies to hell?

The quotes conerning the law seem to me to be more of a warning that following the jewish law isn't a guarantee to heaven. And the gentiles it speaks of may as well be believers in Christ without being in possesion of the jewish law. They are also to be judged by Christ in the end although I can see different interpretations to that.

There's also these quotes posted here by @Thumper

“Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:”
    • Romans 5:12 (KJV)
“Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in sin did my mother conceive me.”
    • Psalm 51:5 (KJV)

Which may argue that when born we personally have already sinned in Adam, and that our only salvation is then to be saved in Christ. 

What's also problematic is the fact that children become sinful *very* quickly as any parent can attest to I'm sure. At 3 year old they are for sure sinning in all kinds of ways, however they are yet incapable of taking the message of Christ to heart. Does this mean they are screwed when they die then no matter what? While they *would* have been saved if they died 2 years ago?

“Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon **all men**, for that all have sinned:”

- Romans 5:12 (KJV)

“Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in **sin** did my mother **conceive** me.”

- Psalm 51:5 (KJV)

*A man's age has no bearing on the fact that he is a sinner and will go to hell upon death should he not obey the Gospel of salvation which is:*

“Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost.”

- Acts 2:38 (KJV)

*As it is also written:*

“Jesus answered, Verily, verily, I say unto thee, **Except** a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he **cannot** enter into the kingdom of God.”

- John 3:5 (KJV)

*May this short message be a blessing to those of you who love the Lord Jesus Christ and have ears to hear.*

“He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.”

- Matthew 11:15 (KJV)

Amen.


/Thumper
